title: Infrastructure as Code Drift
context: Teams adopt Infrastructure as Code (Terraform, Pulumi, CloudFormation) to make infrastructure reproducible, version-controlled, and auditable. The initial setup is clean. Then someone makes a manual change in the console during an incident. Then another. Then a new service gets provisioned outside IaC because it was 'just a quick test.' Drift accumulates. The IaC state file says one thing, reality says another. The reproducible infrastructure is no longer reproducible, and nobody knows which version is correct.
hypothesis: Infrastructure as Code ensures reproducible, auditable infrastructure that matches the declared state.

chain.root: Adopt Infrastructure as Code for all infrastructure management

effects.label: Manual changes during incidents create drift

children.label: Incident response requires speed — IaC is too slow in emergencies
Console changes made during incidents never get back-ported to IaC
Each manual change makes the next one more likely — drift normalizes

effects.label: State file becomes source of truth that isn't true
effects.impact: State file diverges from actual infrastructure

children.label: terraform plan shows changes that would break production if applied
Teams afraid to run terraform apply because they don't trust the state
State file corruption or loss can be catastrophic — no way to reconcile

effects.label: IaC complexity grows faster than team expertise
effects.impact: Terraform codebases become as complex as application code

children.label: Modules, workspaces, providers, and state management require deep expertise
Debugging IaC failures requires understanding both the tool and the cloud provider
Blast radius of IaC mistakes can be enormous — one bad apply destroys production

effects.label: Reproducibility promise breaks down
effects.impact: Can't reliably recreate infrastructure from code alone

children.label: Disaster recovery plans that depend on IaC fail when drift exists
New environments don't match production because of undocumented manual changes

dontIf: Your team doesn't have the discipline to back-port every manual change to IaC
You don't have automated drift detection running continuously
ifYouMust: Run automated drift detection daily — alert on any divergence immediately
Establish a 'no manual changes' policy with exceptions requiring documented back-port within 24 hours
Use policy-as-code (OPA, Sentinel) to prevent manual changes that bypass IaC
Keep state files in remote backends with locking and versioning

alternatives.name: GitOps with drift detection
alternatives.note: Continuous reconciliation between declared state and actual state — auto-corrects drift

alternatives.name: Immutable infrastructure
alternatives.note: Never modify — destroy and recreate. Eliminates drift by design.

alternatives.name: Platform engineering abstraction
alternatives.note: Internal platform handles IaC complexity — developers interact with simpler abstractions

falsifiability: Organizations using IaC maintain zero drift between declared and actual infrastructure state over 12 months
Manual changes during incidents are consistently back-ported to IaC within 24 hours
IaC state files accurately represent production infrastructure at all times without drift detection tooling

seo.description: 60-70% of organizations experience IaC drift. Manual incident changes never get back-ported. The reproducible infrastructure promise breaks down as state files diverge from reality.
